Article.Abstract: CD8(+) T cells are thought to play an important role in protective immunity to tuberculosis. Although several nonprotein ligands have been identified for CD1-restricted CD8(+) CTLs, epitopes for classical MHC class I-restricted CD8(+) T cells, which most likely represent a majority among CD8(+) T cells, have remained ill defined. HLA-A*0201 is one of the most prevalent class I alleles, with a frequency of over 30% in most populations. HLA-A2/K(b) transgenic mice were shown to provide a powerful model for studying induction of HLA-A*0201-restricted immune responses in vivo. The Ag85 complex, a major component of secreted Mycobacterium tuberculosis proteins, induces strong CD4(+) T cell responses in M. tuberculosis-infected individuals, and protection against tuberculosis in Ag85-DNA-immunized animals. In this study, we demonstrate the presence of HLA class I-restricted, CD8(+) T cells against Ag85B of M. tuberculosis in HLA-A2/K(b) transgenic mice and HLA-A*0201(+) humans. Moreover, two immunodominant Ag85 peptide epitopes for HLA-A*0201-restricted, M. tuberculosis-reactive CD8(+) CTLs were identified. These CD8(+) T cells produced IFN-gamma and TNF-alpha and recognized Ag-pulsed or bacillus Calmette-Guérin-infected, HLA-A*0201-positive, but not HLA-A*0201-negative or uninfected human macrophages. This CTL-mediated killing was blocked by anti-CD8 or anti-HLA class I mAb. Using fluorescent peptide/HLA-A*0201 tetramers, Ag85-specific CD8(+) T cells could be visualized in bacillus Calmette-Guérin-responsive, HLA-A*0201(+) individuals. Collectively, our results demonstrate the presence of HLA class I-restricted CD8(+) CTL against a major Ag of M. tuberculosis and identify Ag85B epitopes that are strongly recognized by HLA-A*0201-restricted CD8(+) T cells in humans and mice. These epitopes thus represent potential subunit components for the design of vaccines against tuberculosis.
Article.ArticleTitle: Identification of major epitopes of Mycobacterium tuberculosis AG85B that are recognized by HLA-A*0201-restricted CD8+ T cells in HLA-transgenic mice and humans.
Article.Affiliations: Department of Immunohematology and Blood Transfusion, Leiden University Medical Center, Leiden, The Netherlands. ageluk@lumc.nl.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: HLA-A*0201+, BCG-responsive individuals PBMCs were used. Previous vaccination is assumed.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: A similar response was shown for IFN-γ and TNF-α production. Lysis was inhibited when anti-CD8+ or anti-HLA-A*0201 monoclonal antibodies were used. This peptide is strongly conserved in Mycobacterium tuberculosis Antigen 85A and the corresponding Antigen 85A peptide had comparable HLA-A*0201 binding affinity.

FirstInVivoProcess.DoseSchedule: Mice were immunized three times at three-week intervals.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Two weeks after the last immunization, splenocytes were harvested and restimulated with a mix of the 16 best binding Antigen 85B peptides identified in this study.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: This peptide is strongly conserved in Mycobacterium tuberculosis Antigen 85A and the corresponding Antigen 85A peptide had comparable HLA-A*0201 binding affinity. Immunized mice also showed significant levels of serum antibodies to Antigen 85.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: Mice were immunized at the base of the tail.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: A similar response was found for proliferation and IFN-γ production. This peptide is strongly conserved in Mycobacterium tuberculosis Antigen 85A. The corresponding Antigen 85A peptide had comparable HLA-A*0201 binding affinity. Splenocytes were depleted for CD4+ T cells.

HLA-A*0201+, BCG-responsive individuals PBMCs were used. Previous vaccination is assumed.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Cytokine production was only detected when the infected monocytes were matched for HLA-A*0201, indicating the HLA dependency of the response.

Immunization.ImmunizationComments: HLA-A*0201+, BCG-responsive individuals PBMCs were used. Previous vaccination is assumed.

AssayInformation.AssayComments: Virtually no specific staining could be detected in unstimulated, freshly isolated, or frozen PBMC directly ex vivo probably due to the relative low precursor frequency of these cells among circulating PBMC in these healthy individuals. However, in short-term cultured, BCG-stimulated PBMCs (STCL) from these donors, CD8+ T cells were detected that bound to HLA-A*0201/Ag85B p199â€“207 tetramers, ranging from 6 to 23% of the CD8+ T cell population.
